    Higher differentiability of usual operations #

    We prove that the usual operations (addition, multiplication, difference, composition, and so on) preserve C^n functions. We also expand the API around C^n functions.

    Main results #

    • ContDiff.comp states that the composition of two C^n functions is C^n.

    Similar results are given for C^n functions on domains.

    Notations #

    We use the notation E [√ón]‚ÜíL[ùïú] F for the space of continuous multilinear maps on E^n with values in F. This is the space in which the n-th derivative of a function from E to F lives.

    In this file, we denote (‚ä§ : ‚Ñï‚àû) : WithTop ‚Ñï‚àû with ‚àû and ‚ä§ : WithTop ‚Ñï‚àû with œâ.

    Tags #

    derivative, differentiability, higher derivative, C^n, multilinear, Taylor series, formal series

    The cartesian product of C^n functions is C^n.

    Composition of C^n functions #

    We show that the composition of C^n functions is C^n. One way to do this would be to use the following simple inductive proof. Assume it is done for n. Then, to check it for n+1, one needs to check that the derivative of g ‚àò f is C^n, i.e., that Dg(f x) ‚¨ù Df(x) is C^n. The term Dg (f x) is the composition of two C^n functions, so it is C^n by the inductive assumption. The term Df(x) is also C^n. Then, the matrix multiplication is the application of a bilinear map (which is C^‚àû, and therefore C^n) to x ‚Ü¶ (Dg(f x), Df x). As the composition of two C^n maps, it is again C^n, and we are done.

    There are two difficulties in this proof.

    The first one is that it is an induction over all Banach spaces. In Lean, this is only possible if they belong to a fixed universe. One could formalize this by first proving the statement in this case, and then extending the result to general universes by embedding all the spaces we consider in a common universe through ULift.

    The second one is that it does not work cleanly for analytic maps: for this case, we need to exhibit a whole sequence of derivatives which are all analytic, not just finitely many of them, so an induction is never enough at a finite step.

    Both these difficulties can be overcome with some cost. However, we choose a different path: we write down an explicit formula for the n-th derivative of g ‚àò f in terms of derivatives of g and f (this is the formula of Faa-Di Bruno) and use this formula to get a suitable Taylor expansion for g ‚àò f. Writing down the formula of Faa-Di Bruno is not easy as the formula is quite intricate, but it is also useful for other purposes and once available it makes the proof here essentially trivial.

    source

    theorem ContDiffWithinAt.hasFDerivWithinAt_nhds {ùïú : Type u_1} [NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {E : Type uE} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace ùïú E] {F : Type uF} [NormedAddCommGroup F] [NormedSpace ùïú F] {G : Type uG} [NormedAddCommGroup G] [NormedSpace ùïú G] {s : Set E} {n : WithTop ‚Ñï‚àû} {f : E ‚Üí F ‚Üí G} {g : E ‚Üí F} {t : Set F} (hn : n ‚â† ‚Üë‚ä§) {x‚ÇÄ : E} (hf : ContDiffWithinAt ùïú (n + 1) (Function.uncurry f) (insert x‚ÇÄ s √óÀ¢ t) (x‚ÇÄ, g x‚ÇÄ)) (hg : ContDiffWithinAt ùïú n g s x‚ÇÄ) (hgt : t ‚àà nhdsWithin (g x‚ÇÄ) (g '' s)) :
    ‚àÉ v ‚àà nhdsWithin x‚ÇÄ (insert x‚ÇÄ s), v ‚äÜ insert x‚ÇÄ s ‚àß ‚àÉ (f' : E ‚Üí F ‚ÜíL[ùïú] G), (‚àÄ x ‚àà v, HasFDerivWithinAt (f x) (f' x) t (g x)) ‚àß ContDiffWithinAt ùïú n (fun (x : E) => f' x) s x‚ÇÄ

    One direction of contDiffWithinAt_succ_iff_hasFDerivWithinAt, but where all derivatives are taken within the same set. Version for partial derivatives / functions with parameters. If f x is a C^n+1 family of functions and g x is a C^n family of points, then the derivative of f x at g x depends in a C^n way on x. We give a general version of this fact relative to sets which may not have unique derivatives, in the following form. If f : E √ó F ‚Üí G is C^n+1 at (x‚ÇÄ, g(x‚ÇÄ)) in (s ‚à™ {x‚ÇÄ}) √ó t ‚äÜ E √ó F and g : E ‚Üí F is C^n at x‚ÇÄ within some set s ‚äÜ E, then there is a function f' : E ‚Üí F ‚ÜíL[ùïú] G that is C^n at x‚ÇÄ within s such that for all x sufficiently close to x‚ÇÄ within s ‚à™ {x‚ÇÄ} the function y ‚Ü¶ f x y has derivative f' x at g x within t ‚äÜ F. For convenience, we return an explicit set of x's where this holds that is a subset of s ‚à™ {x‚ÇÄ}. We need one additional condition, namely that t is a neighborhood of g(x‚ÇÄ) within g '' s.

    theorem PartialHomeomorph.contDiffAt_symm {ùïú : Type u_1} [NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {E : Type uE} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace ùïú E] {F : Type uF} [NormedAddCommGroup F] [NormedSpace ùïú F] {n : WithTop ‚Ñï‚àû} [CompleteSpace E] (f : PartialHomeomorph E F) {f‚ÇÄ' : E ‚âÉL[ùïú] F} {a : F} (ha : a ‚àà f.target) (hf‚ÇÄ' : HasFDerivAt (‚Üëf) (‚Üëf‚ÇÄ') (‚Üëf.symm a)) (hf : ContDiffAt ùïú n (‚Üëf) (‚Üëf.symm a)) :
    ContDiffAt ùïú n (‚Üëf.symm) a

    If f is a local homeomorphism and the point a is in its target, and if f is n times continuously differentiable at f.symm a, and if the derivative at f.symm a is a continuous linear equivalence, then f.symm is n times continuously differentiable at the point a.

    This is one of the easy parts of the inverse function theorem: it assumes that we already have an inverse function.

    def PartialHomeomorph.restrContDiff (ùïú : Type u_1) [NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {E : Type uE} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace ùïú E] {F : Type uF} [NormedAddCommGroup F] [NormedSpace ùïú F] (f : PartialHomeomorph E F) (n : WithTop ‚Ñï‚àû) (hn : n ‚â† ‚Üë‚ä§) :
    PartialHomeomorph E F

    Restrict a partial homeomorphism to the subsets of the source and target that consist of points x ‚àà f.source, y = f x ‚àà f.target such that f is C^n at x and f.symm is C^n at y.

    Note that n is a natural number or œâ, but not ‚àû, because the set of points of C^‚àû-smoothness of f is not guaranteed to be open.
